title: AI Prompting Mastery
description: Master the art of prompt engineering with proven techniques for any AI model

challenges.title: The Fundamentals of Good Prompts
challenges.description: Learn the core principles that make prompts effective
challenges.instructions: Teach the user the five pillars of effective prompting: Clarity (be specific), Completeness (provide context), Conciseness (avoid fluff), Correctness (accurate info), and Courtesy (polite tone). Show examples of bad vs good prompts.
hints: Bad: 'Write something about dogs' â†’ Good: 'Write a 200-word article about Golden Retriever training for first-time owners'
Be specific about format, length, tone, and audience
Include relevant context about your use case
Avoid vague terms like 'something', 'good', 'nice'
State constraints upfront (word count, style, restrictions)

challenges.title: Master the CLEAR Framework
challenges.description: Use CLEAR: Context, Length, Examples, Audience, Role
challenges.instructions: Teach the CLEAR prompting framework: Context (background info), Length (desired output size), Examples (show what you want), Audience (who it's for), Role (AI's perspective). Practice building prompts with all five elements.
hints: Context: 'I'm building a SaaS product for project management'
Length: 'Write a 500-word blog post' or 'Create 5 bullet points'
Examples: 'Similar to how Notion writes their docs'
Audience: 'For non-technical startup founders'
Role: 'You are a product marketing expert with 10 years experience'

challenges.title: Role-Based Prompting
challenges.description: Assign specific roles to get expert-level responses
challenges.instructions: Show how assigning a role transforms AI responses. Practice using specific roles like 'senior software architect', 'copywriting expert', 'financial advisor'. Compare generic vs role-based outputs.
hints: Generic: 'Explain machine learning' vs Role: 'As a university professor, explain ML to freshmen'
Use specific expertise: 'You are a senior DevOps engineer with AWS certifications'
Add experience level: 'with 15 years experience' or 'specializing in startups'
Include relevant background: 'who has worked at FAANG companies'
Define perspective: 'from a practical, hands-on approach'

challenges.title: Few-Shot Prompting
challenges.description: Provide examples to guide AI output format and style
challenges.instructions: Teach few-shot learning: give 2-3 examples of desired output before asking for new content. Show how examples dramatically improve consistency and quality.
hints: Provide 2-3 examples of the exact format you want
Example: 'Input: happy â†’ Output: ðŸ˜Š | Input: sad â†’ Output: ðŸ˜¢ | Now convert: excited'
Match style, tone, structure, and length in examples
Use examples to show edge cases or specific requirements
More examples = better pattern recognition (but diminishing returns after 3-5)

challenges.title: Chain-of-Thought Reasoning
challenges.description: Get step-by-step reasoning for complex problems
challenges.instructions: Teach chain-of-thought (CoT) prompting: add 'Let's think step by step' or 'Show your reasoning' to get detailed problem-solving. Compare direct answers vs CoT answers for complex tasks.
hints: Add: 'Let's think step by step' before complex questions
Use: 'Explain your reasoning process'
Or: 'Break this down into logical steps'
CoT improves accuracy on math, logic, multi-step problems
Review reasoning to catch errors in logic

challenges.title: Context and Constraints
challenges.description: Provide relevant context and clear boundaries
challenges.instructions: Show how context improves relevance and constraints prevent unwanted outputs. Practice adding background info, defining what to avoid, and setting boundaries (length, style, topics).
hints: Context: 'I'm creating content for a B2B SaaS targeting CTOs'
Constraints: 'Do not use jargon, keep under 300 words, avoid technical acronyms'
Define scope: 'Focus only on React hooks, not class components'
Set tone: 'Use a professional but conversational tone'
Specify exclusions: 'Don't mention competitors or pricing'

challenges.title: Output Formatting
challenges.description: Specify exact format for structured responses
challenges.instructions: Teach how to request specific formats: JSON, markdown, tables, bullet points, code blocks. Show how formatting instructions make outputs immediately usable.
hints: Request JSON: 'Output as JSON with fields: name, description, category'
Tables: 'Present the data in a markdown table with columns A, B, C'
Code: 'Provide code in Python with inline comments'
Lists: 'Give me 5 bullet points, each starting with an action verb'
Templates: 'Use this format: [Title] | [Date] | [Description]'

challenges.title: Iterative Refinement
challenges.instructions: Teach the art of refinement: start broad, then iterate with specific feedback. Show how to critique and improve AI outputs with targeted follow-ups.
hints: Start: 'Write a product description for wireless earbuds'
Refine: 'Make it more concise and focus on battery life'
Polish: 'Add a call-to-action and make the tone more exciting'
Adjust: 'Remove technical specs and focus on lifestyle benefits'
Each iteration builds on previous output

challenges.title: Prompt Templates and Reusability
challenges.description: Create reusable prompt templates for common tasks
challenges.instructions: Show how to build prompt templates with placeholders for repeated tasks. Create templates for common use cases: emails, code reviews, content creation, analysis.
hints: Template: 'As a [ROLE], create a [OUTPUT_TYPE] about [TOPIC] for [AUDIENCE] in [TONE]'
Email template: 'Write a [formal/casual] email to [recipient] about [subject] with [key_points]'
Code review: 'Review this [language] code for [criteria]. Provide feedback in [format]'
Save successful prompts as templates
Build a personal prompt library

challenges.title: Advanced Techniques: Prompt Chaining
challenges.description: Break complex tasks into sequential prompts
challenges.instructions: Teach prompt chaining: split large tasks into smaller prompts where each output feeds the next. Show examples of research â†’ outline â†’ writing â†’ editing chains.
hints: Step 1: 'Research key points about [topic]'
Step 2: 'Using the above research, create a detailed outline'
Step 3: 'Write section 1 based on the outline'
Step 4: 'Edit for clarity and conciseness'
Each prompt refines or builds on previous outputs

challenges.title: Meta-Prompting
challenges.description: Ask AI to help you write better prompts
challenges.instructions: Teach meta-prompting: use AI to improve your prompts. Ask 'How can I improve this prompt?' or 'Suggest a better way to ask this question'. Show the prompt improvement cycle.
hints: Ask: 'I want to [goal]. How should I prompt you to get the best results?'
Try: 'Review this prompt and suggest improvements: [your prompt]'
Use: 'What information would help you give a better answer?'
Request: 'Rewrite my prompt to be more effective'
Learn from AI's suggestions to level up your prompting

challenges.title: Domain-Specific Prompting
challenges.description: Tailor prompts for specific domains: code, writing, analysis
challenges.instructions: Teach domain-specific best practices. For code: specify language, libraries, style. For writing: define audience, tone, structure. For analysis: state methodology, metrics, format.
hints: Code: 'Write Python code using pandas and numpy, with type hints and docstrings'
Writing: 'Write a blog post in AP style for technical professionals'
Analysis: 'Analyze this data using descriptive statistics and create visualizations'
Design: 'Create a UI component following Material Design principles'
Each domain has specific requirements and conventions

challenges.title: Handling Ambiguity and Edge Cases
challenges.description: Write prompts that handle uncertainty gracefully
challenges.instructions: Show how to write robust prompts that account for ambiguity: 'If X is unclear, assume Y', 'For edge cases, use Z approach'. Teach defensive prompting.
hints: Add: 'If information is missing, state your assumptions'
Include: 'For ambiguous cases, provide multiple options'
Specify: 'If uncertain, ask clarifying questions rather than guessing'
Define: 'Handle edge cases by [specific approach]'
Anticipate and address potential misunderstandings

challenges.title: Negative Prompting
challenges.description: Use 'do not' instructions to avoid unwanted outputs
challenges.instructions: Teach negative prompting: explicitly state what to avoid. Show how 'do not include X' can be as important as 'include Y'. Practice with exclusions and restrictions.
hints: Avoid fluff: 'Do not include filler words or generic statements'
Stay focused: 'Do not discuss topics outside of [scope]'
Skip basics: 'Do not explain basic concepts, assume advanced knowledge'
Format: 'Do not use bullet points, write in paragraph form'
Combine positive and negative instructions for precision

challenges.title: Evaluation and Testing
challenges.instructions: Teach how to evaluate prompt quality: test with multiple inputs, compare outputs, measure consistency. Show A/B testing of prompts and iterating based on results.
hints: Test same prompt with different inputs to check consistency
Compare outputs from different prompt versions
Create rubrics: accuracy, relevance, format, tone
A/B test: try two approaches and measure which works better
Document successful prompts and patterns in a knowledge base
